description: A deep nested fashion taxonomy combining best practices from Whatnot (context), Google (standardization), and Shopify (depth). Each product should map to exactly ONE leaf node.

design_principles.taxonomy_structure: Organized by WHAT the product IS (product type), not WHO it's for or WHEN to wear it
design_principles.leaf_node_rule: Each product must fall under exactly one leaf node

in_taxonomy: Specific garment style (T-Shirt, Jeans, Maxi Dress)
Functional subcategories that change the product nature
as_attributes: Size type (Plus, Petite, Maternity, Big & Tall)

children.name: Tops
children.description: Upper body garments worn on the torso

children.name: T-Shirts
children.description: Short or long sleeve shirts, typically casual

example_1.taxonomy_path: Fashion & Apparel > Tops > T-Shirts > Graphic T-Shirts

example_2.taxonomy_path: Fashion & Apparel > Dresses & Jumpsuits > Casual Dresses > Casual Maxi Dresses

example_3.taxonomy_path: Fashion & Apparel > Activewear & Athletic > Athletic Bottoms > Athletic Joggers

example_4.taxonomy_path: Fashion & Apparel > Accessories > Bags > Crossbody Bags

implementation_notes.single_leaf_node: Each product should be classified under exactly ONE leaf node based on what the product fundamentally IS
implementation_notes.attribute_flexibility: Use attributes to describe WHO it's for, WHEN to wear it, and other descriptive properties
implementation_notes.context_via_attributes: Whatnot's context-based categories (Vintage, Boutiques) become attributes (era_style_period, source_type)
implementation_notes.avoid_redundancy: Don't duplicate categories for different audiences - use gender as an attribute instead
implementation_notes.extensibility: New attributes can be added without restructuring the taxonomy tree
implementation_notes.search_optimization: Products can be filtered by any combination of taxonomy + attributes
